verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Ezekiel often introduces divine messages with a formula that underscores prophetic authority. This establishes the seriousness of God’s revelation, similar to other prophetic texts.

verses.text: Son of man, how is the wood of the vine better than any branch that is among the trees of the forest?
verses.comment: The image of Israel as a vine is consistent with passages like Psalm 80 and Isaiah 5, where the people are likened to a vineyard. Christ later calls Himself the 'true vine' (John 15:1-6), fulfilling and transforming the vine symbol.

verses.text: Is wood taken from it to make any object? Or do men take a peg from it to hang any vessel on?
verses.comment: Vine wood is not useful for construction, highlighting the point that Israel’s true greatness is spiritual, not in earthly strength or usefulness. Compare with the imagery of a peg for security in Isa. 22:23.

verses.text: Behold, it is thrown into the fire for fuel. The fire devours both ends of it, and the middle is burned. Is it useful for any work?
verses.comment: The burnt vine represents judgment. In John 15:6, Jesus uses the same image to warn about those who do not abide in Him being cast aside and burned.

verses.text: Look, when it was whole it was not used for any work. How much less, when the fire has consumed and scorched it, can it ever be useful for any work?
verses.comment: The uselessness of burned wood mirrors Israel’s state after judgment. This foreshadows the New Covenant, where fruitfulness comes from union with Christ.

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord GOD says: Like the wood of the vine among the trees of the forest, which I have given to the fire for fuel, so will I give up the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: God’s people, set apart yet unfaithful, receive just consequences. This judgment is also a call to true faithfulness and fruit-bearing, which is key for enduring in God’s household.

verses.text: I will set my face against them. Even though they come out of the fire, the fire will yet consume them. Then you will know that I am the LORD, when I set my face against them.
verses.comment: 'Setting my face against' echoes God’s determined judgment. This knowledge of the LORD through discipline prepares for ultimate reconciliation—fulfilled fully in Christ’s reconciling sacrifice.

verses.text: And I will make the land desolate because they have acted unfaithfully, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Desolation is linked to unfaithfulness. Yet, as the story of salvation unfolds, God’s plan is to restore and bring fruitful life through His covenant—especially through the Church, built on apostolic succession and unity. See Matt. 16:18 for fulfillment imagery.
